results.title: Tango Bar
results.creator_credit: Marcos Zurinaga, Roberto Gandara, Juan Carlos Codazzi, Zaga Films and Beco Films
results.brief_description: Raul Julia stars in this story of a trio of performers who play, sing and dance at the “Tango Bar” in Buenos Aires. The trio are split apart by a revolution in Argentina and reunited after 10 years of exile. Whilst the plot of “Tango Bar” revolves around the story of Pedro (Raul Julia), Elena (Valeria Lynch) and Antonio (Ruben Jaurez), it is primarily a tribute to Tango in Argentina. As they perform their show at the Tango Bar - singing, dancing tango and talking about its history and politics, the film flashes to dance sequences of tango performed at various times in the history of the dance form. In Spanish with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marcos Zurinaga, Roberto Gandara, Juan Carlos Codazzi, Zaga Films and Beco Films

results.title: Tango among friends
results.brief_description: Tangos Among Friends is a personal pilgrimage by pianist and conductor Daniel Barenboim to his hometown of Buenos Aires. The film intersperses Barenboim’s exposition of the history of the development of Tango music in Argentina with excerpts from concerts where Barenboim performs pieces by renowned Tango composers (such as Carlos Gardel and Piazzolla), with double bass player Hector Console and accordionist Rodolfo Mederos. Barenboim also performs a duet with Placido Domingo and there is also an example of Tango dancing. “Tangos Among Friends” is a fascinating journey into the wonders of Tango music and dance as well as the cultural life of Argentina. The video comes with a booklet that gives details of the songs included in the film and of the three musicians performing the music. In English and Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Tango
results.creator_credit: Carlos Saura, Juan Carlos Codazzi, Carlos L. Mentasti, Luis Scalella, Terraplen Producciones, Saura Films, Hollywood Partners, Beco Films, Astrolabio Producciones, Argentina Sono Films, Alma Ata International Pictures, Adela Pictures and Pandora Cinema
results.brief_description: This Argentinian/Spanish co-production is a dance film within a dance film which blurs the lines between rehearsal, real life and performance. Set in Buenos Aires, the film’s slender plot centres on the creative processes of a womanising, middle-aged director who, whilst recovering from a marriage breakup, decides to make a musical centred on the tango. Bearing a close resemblance to the protagonist in Fellini’s “8 1/2” the director dwells on his childhood memories, middle-aged regret and wounded heart as he prepares his film. With only the thinnest of narrative threads linking scenes and moments together, the film relies far more heavily on colour, movement and music than on dialogue or characterisation. The bulk of the film is devoted to expertly-choreographed performances which explore both the fictional director’s personal demons and moments in Argentinian history. Stunningly photographed by Vittorio Storaro. Cast: Miguel Angel Sola, Cecilia Narova, Mia Maestro, Juan Carlos Copes, Carlos Rivarola. In Spanish with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Carlos Saura, Juan Carlos Codazzi, Carlos L. Mentasti, Luis Scalella, Terraplen Producciones, Saura Films, Hollywood Partners, Beco Films, Astrolabio Producciones, Argentina Sono Films, Alma Ata International Pictures, Adela Pictures and Pandora Cinema

results.title: Tanglewood Music School and Music Festival
results.creator_credit: United States Information Service and MPO Productions
results.brief_description: A record of the pioneering work being done by Serge Koussevitsky in establishing the music festival and summer school held each year at Berkshire, USA. With the assistance of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, such composers as Leonard Bernstein and Aaron Copland help and stimulate young students of composition in their work. The film concludes with a premier performance of “The Last words of David” by Randall Thompson.

results.title: Tangerine dream
results.creator_credit: Keri Light and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: A pharmaceutical misadventure which takes place in a rainbow laundromat ends with Bonnie (Tania Lacy), and Simon (Ben Mendelsohn) speaking in visionary gibberish as they flash Bonnie’s laundry. They inhabit an indefinable world, between midnight and dawn, within the murky depths of paranoia and ambition.

results.title: Tangents
results.brief_description: Explains that in problems involving right-angled triangles a choice exists between using sine or cosine in the solution. Discusses the use of tangents as a simpler function for solving some problems.

results.title: Tanganyika: new nation
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and British Pathe News
results.brief_description: A record of HRH Prince Philip’s visit to Tanganyika during the Independence celebrations. After arrival in the capital city, Dar es Salaam, the Duke, with the then Prime Minister, Julius Nyerere, is seen attending several events to mark the occasion, including a tattoo and display, the Independence Day Ceremonial, a reception at Government House, and the State Opening of the Tanganyika Parliament.

results.title: Tanaka
results.brief_description: When Mori, a young Japanese man, is sent by his family to Australia to oversee the funeral of his uncle, Hiroshi, he is thrust into a world of cross-cultural love, grief and misunderstanding. Estranged from Hiroshi for many years, Mori and his family are unaware that he was gay and lived with his Australian lover Ron for decades. As he gets to know his uncle for the first time through videos, photographs, and the stories Ron tells him, Mori must now come to terms with this fresh knowledge and find a way to fulfil his traditional obligations to his family while remaining true to his uncle’s spirit. A powerful and poignant film. Winner of Best Australian Short, Melbourne Queer Film Festival 2003. Cast includes Morihiko Hasebe, Ronald Jacobson, Chris Bartlett, Ant Keogh, Rohan Timlock, Takuji Hasebe, Yukio Kimura.

results.title: Tan Sitong = Tan Si Tong
results.creator_credit: Chen Jialin and Changchun Film Studio
results.brief_description:
Despite centering around the heroic personality of the eponymous Qing Dynasty official Tan Sitong (1865—1898), the film is actually an examination of the events and internal pressures that indirectly led to the fall of the Qing Dynasty. In her waning years, the Empress Dowager Ci Xi was still the one pulling the strings to the incumbent puppet Emperor Guangxu.

Acting out her will through the viciously corrupt internal bureacracy of eunuchs in the Forbidden City, Ci Xi and her lackies are shown by the film to lack confidence in the abilities of their own people. This led to constant double-dealings and secret negotiations that ultimately whittled away what little self-esteem the nation has left.

Far from being a naive accessory, Emperor Guangxu sees this degradation for what it is and struggles to appoint just and upstanding officials to carry out a revolutionary new wave of reforms designed to combat the rampant corruption across the country. Led by Kang Youwei, a handful of daring men advance the interests of the struggling emperor, but are eventually undermined by overwhelming odds and the vicious interests of the government.

Tan Sitong, the right-hand man of Kang Youwei, who is in charge of carrying out the reforms, is a target of government slander. Although Tan was not the central hero of the story, he showed incredible persistence in the face of accusations and misunderstandings, even by the emperor, whose ear was constantly poisoned by Imperial eunuchs.

Tan is the champion of all the unsung heroes, and comes to a gritty end for his trouble. After he parts with his indentured servant and wife, he and his friends are rounded up by the imperial guard and taken off in cages. He spends his final hours sitting in prison, writing poetry on the walls with a piece of charcoal. Then he and five other reformists are executed (Kang Youwei was clever and ran away, but this explains why the movie is not about him).

The film ends with an impressive urban scene of the martyrs being paraded on crucifixes down the main road while hordes of onlookers watch the execution. The scene provides an illustrious example of a high-ranking execution during the Qing dynasty. As the official presiding over the execution issues their death warrants Tan’s wife bites her finger and writes in blood over his coffin “Here Lies a Good Man”.

Cultural History of the Film:

The cast is long and the plot intricate, but the film is highly detailed and — for all intents and purposes — is highly informative.
(4 stars - James Donald; June 9, 2011)
